Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: First I need to understand the process flow The assumed steps are Register Order Credit Check Validate Stock Confirm Shipment Ship Goods Issue Invoice and Receive Payment Each order should follow this sequence Looking at the sample data I notice Order 1001 follows all steps Order 1002 has a Complete Shipment before Credit Check which is out of order Order 1003 skips Confirm Shipment and starts Shipping right after Credit Check Order 1004 skips Validate Stock and has Receive Payment immediately after Registration These are clear sequence anomalies

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Next hypothetical causes Possible reasons for the incorrect sequence in 1002 could be a system error in scheduling For 1003 maybe a manual override skipped the Confirm Shipment step In 1004 missing Validate Stock might indicate a broken process or a quick payment without verification

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: When writing the SQL queries I should ensure they check for out-of-sequence events missing steps and resource involvement Queries need to filter case_ids where certain events dont follow the expected order check for missing events and see if resources overlap points where steps should have been sequential Also using JOINs with resources and orders tables would add context like checking if Confirm Shipment precedes Ship Goods and creating a resource table to ensure single resource per step

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: The user wants the LLM to generate these queries without hints so the prompt needs to clearly list the five behaviors to check sequence missing steps short durations resource overlaps activity gaps and specify the schema details Including the step order and table relationships is crucial for the LLM to construct accurate SQL statements Ensuring the prompt is thorough but not leading will help the LLM produce the required investigative queries independently
